div.l: Now sirs quod Oswalde the Reue
I pray you alle that ye you not greue
Though that I answere and somdel set his hovn
For leuefulle is with force for to sown
This dronken myller hath tolde vs here
Howe that begiled was a maister Carpentere
Parauenture in scorne for that I am one
And by yoʳur leue I shalle hym quyte anone
Right in his cherles termes wolle I speke
I pray to god his necke mowe to breke
He can welle in myn eye se a stalke
But in his owne he cannot se a balke
Here endeth the Reuees prologe
and here begynntth his tale
AT trompyngton not fer from Cambrige
There goth a broke and ouer that a brige
Vppon the whiche broke there stondeth a mylle
And this is verey soth that I you telle
A Miller was there dwellynge many a day
As eny pecok he was proude and gay
Pipe he coude and fysh and nettes bete
And turne cuppis and welle wrastille ⁊and lepe
And by his belt he bare a longe panade
And of a swerde fulle trenchant was the blade
A ioly popper bare he in his pouche
There was nomān for peril durst hȳm touche
A sheffeld thwytle bare he in his hose
Ronde was his face ⁊and cāmmoyse was his nose
Also pilled as an ape was his skulle
He was a Markett betere at the fulle
There durst no wight hond vppōn hȳm legge
That he ne swore anone he shuld abegge
A thef he was forsoth of corne and mele
And that a sligh and vsant for to stele
